headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of March 27, 2019

headline: RBNZ Adopts Dovish Outlook Fearing Global Downturn
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand kept interest rates on hold at a policy meeting on Wednesday, but warned the next move in interest rates was more likely to be down given an increasingly uncertain global economy.

headline: Apple, Qualcomm Trade Blows in Patent Fight
summary: Apple and Qualcomm each notched victories from a U.S. trade body in their yearslong feud over patent licensing, hardening the divide between them ahead of a federal trial slated to begin next month.

headline: J.C. Penney Taps New CFO as Retailer Fights Falling Sales
summary: J.C. Penney named a new finance chief, filling the post after a nearly six-month vacancy as the retailer battles falling sales and searches for a turnaround strategy.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Wife Defends Mental-Health Initiative
summary: Chirlane McCray, wife of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, defended the funding and effectiveness of ThriveNYC during a New York City Council hearing.

headline: New York Leaders Retreat From Annual Tax on High-Priced Second Homes
summary: State lawmakers are leaders are backing away from a proposed tax on high-end properties owned by non-New York City residents, after industry leaders warned it could disrupt the already weak luxury real-estate market.

headline: Conservative Justices Hesitant About Judicial Remedy for Gerrymandering
summary: The Supreme Court again appeared hesitant to embrace a judicial remedy for partisan gerrymandering, with no justice in the conservative majority expressing enthusiasm for myriad formulas to address an age-old practice of American politics.

headline: Acting Pentagon Chief Orders New Review of a Deadly 2017 Ambush
summary: Acting Defense Secretary Pat Shanahan told lawmakers that he has ordered a new review into the 2017 ambush in Niger that killed four American troops.

headline: Two Parents in College-Admissions Scheme Indicted on New Charge
summary: Two parents allegedly involved in the college-admissions scheme were indicted on a new charge of money-laundering, and other parents are likely to face additional charges as well.

headline: Nancy Pelosi, at Aipac Gathering, Condemns Anti-Semitism
summary: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi at an annual conference of a pro-Israel lobby said Democrats remained strong allies of Israel, following comments by two lawmakers in her party that critics said were anti-Semitic.

headline: The Case For—and Against—Reparations
summary: Students across America debate what the country owes its black citizens.

headline: Democrats Vote ‘Present’ on Climate
summary: Democrats are upset they had to vote on their own Green New Deal.

headline: House Effort to Override Trump Veto on Emergency Comes Up Short
summary: House Democrats’ effort to override President Trump’s veto of a measure aimed at rolling back his emergency declaration over a border wall was defeated in a 248-181 vote.

headline: The Court vs. the Regulatory State
summary: The Justices can restore their power to check bureaucratic excess.

headline: Smollett Gets a Pass in Chicago
summary: State prosecutors drop all charges against the ‘Empire’ actor.

headline: What Mueller Won’t Say
summary: Did he investigate the Steele dossier? If not, he didn’t really investigate.

headline: Judge Clears Mercuria Energy Takeover of Fuel Supplier Aegean Marine
summary: A bankruptcy judge said he would approve Mercuria Energy Group’s takeover of marine fuel supplier Aegean Marine Petroleum Network, setting up Aegean’s exit from chapter 11.

headline: NATO Chief to Visit White House Next Week
summary: North Atlantic Treaty Organization Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg and President Trump will discuss the evolving challenges the alliance faces.

headline: Mueller Braced a Nation Under Pressure
summary: His character and the strength of U.S. legal institutions helped us endure the Russia test.

headline: Where Did the Schizophrenics Go?
summary: The number drops to 750,000 from 2.8 million, and spending per patient soars.

headline: ‘The Polar Bear Expedition’ Review: Frozen Doughboys
summary: The American operation in Russia of 1918-19 was misguided. Vague orders from President Wilson doomed it to mission creep.

headline: The Transgender War on Women
summary: The Equality Act sacrifices female safety in restrooms, locker rooms and even domestic-violence shelters.

headline: How Dems Plan to Lock In a Majority
summary: Restrictions on speech, court packing, adding new states—51 senators would be enough to do it all.

headline: Culture Explains Asians’ Educational Success
summary: Black enrollment at New York’s elite public high schools was far higher in the 1930s than today.

headline: Trump-Russia Made for Gripping Fiction
summary: Journalists defend their ‘important digging’ as ‘reality-based.’ What does that even mean?

headline: Trump Administration Again Expands Global Anti-Abortion Policy
summary: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said he is expanding the U.S. policy denying federal funds to foreign nongovernmental organizations that perform or promote abortions.

headline: GE Capital Pays $49 Million Over Petters Ponzi Scheme
summary: General Electric Capital Corp. reached the deal with a bankruptcy trustee who is digging up money for investors in two Florida hedge funds that lost $650 million when the Ponzi scheme collapsed in 2008, according to court papers entered Tuesday in the U.S. District Court in West Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Insurers Creating a Consumer Ratings Service for Cybersecurity
summary: Some of the world’s biggest insurers plan to work together on an assessment of the best cybersecurity available to businesses, an unusual collaboration that highlights the rising dangers posed by hackers.

headline: Alaska Moose Hunter Wins Second Ruling at Supreme Court
summary: The Supreme Court ruled that the federal government couldn’t stop an Alaska moose hunter from using his hovercraft to reach hunting grounds he had visited for decades.

headline: Dollar Rises as Investors Reassess Rate Outlook
summary: The dollar edged higher as a swing in market sentiment caused traders to scale back expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates this year.

headline: Dow Inc. to Replace DowDuPont in DJIA
summary: Dow Inc. will take DowDuPont’s place in the Dow Jones Industrial Average before the start of trading April 2.

headline: Malware Attack on Asus Computers Raises Concerns
summary: Hackers infected computers made by Asustek by embedding malware in the company’s automatic software updates, a sophisticated attack that raises questions about how to tackle such security threats.

headline: Cash-Strapped Illinois and Chicago to Borrow Billions
summary: Illinois and its biggest city are on track to borrow hundreds of millions of dollars starting this week, a test of investors’ willingness to lend to stressed governments prone to spending more money than they bring in.

headline: Avenatti Claims Nike Paid Top NBA Pick, Other College Players
summary: A day after being charged with attempted extortion, attorney Michael Avenatti continued to press his case against Nike, publicizing his claims that the sneaker giant made payments to college athletes and their families.

headline: Senate Democrats Evade GOP Attempt to Expose Rifts Over ‘Green New Deal’
summary: A Republican effort to force Senate Democrats to take a position on a liberal climate-change plan petered out Tuesday.

headline: FTC Orders Broadband Providers to Explain Data Collection Policies
summary: Federal regulators widened their inquiry into consumer privacy matters, ordering seven major broadband providers to detail their data collection policies.

headline: New York Judge Tosses Libel Case Against Dow Jones
summary: A state court judge in New York on Tuesday threw out a case in which a prominent antiquities dealer accused The Wall Street Journal’s publisher of libel.

headline: Senate Panel Considers ‘Red Flag’ Gun Laws in Aftermath of Shootings
summary: A GOP-led Senate committee held a rare gun-control hearing on measures aimed at temporarily blocking people deemed dangerous from accessing firearms, following a wave of states’ decisions to allow such curbs.

headline: The Senate Takes the AOC Test
summary: Politicians admit that America won’t run on renewables.

headline: Journalists Face Prison Over Reporting Pell Sex-Abuse Conviction
summary: More than 20 Australian journalists, including editors of major newspaper titles, face prison and fines for allegedly breaching an order suppressing coverage of a top Vatican official’s child sex-abuse conviction.

headline: Oil Rises as Investors Refocus on Lower Supply
summary: U.S. crude-oil prices rose as analysts weighed signs of falling supply around the globe and looked ahead to the latest figures on U.S. stockpiles.

headline: Southwest 737 MAX Makes Emergency Landing in Florida
summary: A Southwest Airlines Boeing 737 MAX made an emergency landing in Orlando after an engine problem forced pilots to abort a flight to an aircraft parking facility in California.

headline: Dish and Univision End Nine-Month Channel Blackout
summary: Dish Network and Univision Communications agreed to end a nine-month standoff that left the satellite TV company without its most popular Spanish-language programming and drove many customers away.

headline: ‘The World Between Empires: Art and Identity in the Ancient Middle East’ Review: A Creative Explosion Where Superpowers Collide
summary: An exhibition at the Met features some 190 spectacular objects made in important, and often contested, cities along ancient trading routes.

headline: U.S. Government Bonds Little Changed as Auctions Begin
summary: U.S. government bond prices were little changed Tuesday as investors braced for a fresh supply of Treasury and corporate bonds this week.

headline: Home-Builder Stocks Stage a Comeback
summary: Shares of home-building companies are on pace for their best quarter in seven years as a drop in mortgage rates has given home buyers a reprieve.

headline: U.S. Officials Vow to Improve Oversight of Aircraft Certification
summary: The acting head of the Federal Aviation Administration will tell a Senate panel Wednesday that the agency’s approach to regulating safety must “evolve” in the wake of two recent crashes of the Boeing 737 MAX.

headline: Time to Address the Real Poverty-Gap Issues
summary: The major problem with education isn’t the lack of money, the facilities, the teachers, the infrastructure or the teaching methods. Dysfunctional families are the major impediment to better education.

headline: Fed’s Daly: Changes in Labor Market Explain Some of Tepid Wage Gains
summary: San Francisco Fed leader Mary Daly said changes in labor markets and the Federal Reserve’s success in fighting inflation have helped contribute to the economy’s modest level of wage gains.

headline: On the Whole, For-Profit Schools Are Losers
summary: The for-profit college industry accounts for 34% of all federal student-loan defaults despite enrolling just 9% of students.

headline: Nonprofits Need Income Beyond Their Costs
summary: If a health-care system or facility fails to generate money beyond its operational costs, it will quickly cease to be viable and must disappear.

headline: Rule Changes in Pro Sports Always Favor More Offense
summary: Baseball, in particular, is the antithesis of the instant-gratification smartphone era. In response, we now have smaller ballparks and a tiny strike zone to stimulate more runs.

headline: Turkish Lira Firms After Government Moves to Stem Short-Selling
summary: Ankara intensified efforts to prop up the Turkish lira after it suffered steep losses last week, seeking to restore calm on currency markets ahead of local elections dominated by questions over President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s ability to jump-start the shrinking economy.

headline: U.S. Targets ‘Vast Network’ Evading Iran Sanctions
summary: The U.S. Treasury Department blacklisted a “vast network” of more than two dozen companies and individuals operating in the United Arab Emirates and Turkey that U.S. officials said helped Iran’s military finance its operations throughout the region.

headline: U.S. Stocks End Higher
summary: U.S. stocks rose, clawing back some of their sharp declines late last week.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Memoir on Course to Be Most Successful Ever
summary: ‘Becoming’ has sold nearly 10 million copies globally since its release in November, its publisher said. The former first lady’s successful tome is the first in a two-book deal Penguin Random House struck with the Obamas.

headline: China Targets Canadian Glencore Unit in Canola Crackdown
summary: China has revoked the permit for a second Canadian-based grain handler to ship canola seed into the world’s second-largest economy, reinforcing fears among grain growers that they have become collateral damage in the diplomatic dispute between Ottawa and Beijing over a detained Huawei executive.

headline: Higher U.S. Import Tariffs Could Dent Earnings, Credit Ratings at European Car Makers, S&P Says
summary: President Trump last year threatened to impose a tariff of up to 25% on car imports, sparking concern among European car manufacturers.

headline: Judges Consider Legality of Trump’s Blocking Users on Twitter
summary: A federal appeals court weighed whether President Trump’s practice of blocking some users on Twitter violates the free-speech protections of the First Amendment.

headline: Refugee Who Aided Snowden Asks Canada to Grant Asylum to Others Who Helped
summary: Vanessa Rodel says “the situation is really hard” for five other asylum seekers who aided Mr. Snowden and are still living in Hong Kong.

headline: Democrats Signal Renewed Push on Health Care After Mueller Findings
summary: House Democratic leaders are signaling a renewed emphasis on health care and other issues over opposition to President Trump even as they press for the release of special counsel Robert Mueller’s report.

headline: Wildfire Victims Continue Challenge to PG&E Bankruptcy Financing
summary: PG&E has failed to persuade victims of wildfires sparked by its equipment to go along with a $5.5 billion loan, terms of which allow Wall Street banks to start dismantling the company if things go seriously wrong in bankruptcy court.

headline: From ‘Jeannie’ to ‘Brideshead’: TV That Shaped Interior Designers
summary: How the sets of beloved childhood TV shows influenced the aesthetics of world-class interior designers.

headline: U.S. Walks Out of Kabul Meeting
summary: U.S. officials walked out of a meeting that was attended by the top defense aide of Afghan President Ashraf Ghani, in the latest sign of fraying ties between Washington and Kabul over negotiations with the Taliban to end the 18-year Afghan war.

headline: New Jersey’s Right-to-Die Measure Heads to Governor
summary: Advocates in New Jersey finally pushed through legislation that allows terminally ill patients to end their lives, after seven years of coming short.

headline: Wall Street Profits Up in 2018, but Average Bonus Falls
summary: A report by New York state’s comptroller found that the securities industry added 4,700 workers in New York City last year, but the average bonus fell 17%.

headline: Recipes That Start With Seeds—From Sunflower to Poppy
summary: The seeds that give us plants also lend a welcome crunch when sprinkled over a salad or provide a toothsome base for other fresh, healthy springtime dishes.

headline: SEC Addresses Cybersecurity Concerns About Stock-Investor Data
summary: A data repository for all U.S. stock-market activity won’t store some personal information from individual investors, a concession to brokers and traders who worried their data would be a prime target for hackers.

headline: IT Jobs Boost Economy, Even Outside Tech Hubs
summary: Tech employment across all industries last year hit 11.8 million, up 2.3% from 2017, accounting for 7.6% of the U.S. workforce and 10.2% of GDP, according to trade group CompTIA.

headline: Lyft to Price Shares Above Targeted Range of $62 to $68 in IPO
summary: Lyft is expected to price its shares above the targeted range for its initial public offering, in a sign of strong investor demand ahead of the ride-hailing service’s debut.

headline: The 10 Most Covetable Watches from the World’s Top Watch Fair
summary: Each spring, leading watch brands touch down in Basel, Switzerland to showcase their most cutting-edge designs and innovations. Here, a roundup of our favorites from this year’s fair

headline: Steve Earle and the Dukes Review: Saluting a Great ‘Guy’
summary: A new album honors the celebrated singer-songwriter Guy Clark, who died in 2016, by interpreting 16 of his songs.

headline: White House Lawyer Emmet Flood Expected to Leave Post
summary: Emmet Flood, who since last summer has served as the top lawyer representing the White House in the special counsel investigation, is expected to leave his post now that the probe has been completed.

headline: I Laughed, I Cried, I Kissed $6 Million Goodbye
summary: The parent of MoviePass has raised millions despite a delisting, lack of reliable financials and dilution seemingly without end.

headline: Activists May Be Too Late at Bed Bath & Beyond
summary: The home goods retailer’s stock surged on Tuesday after activists launched a proxy fight, but investors should take the money and run as the chain may be beyond fixing.

headline: Europe Embraces China’s Xi—Warily
summary: European leaders sought to present Chinese President Xi Jinping with a united front, pressing him for more reciprocity. But with Europe eager for Chinese business, the trip was seen in Beijing as a success for Mr. Xi.

headline: Feeling the Need for a Speedy Close
summary: As lenders race to offer the fastest closing time for home loans, borrowers end up the real winners

headline: Home Building, New-Home Permits Have Softened This Year
summary: A gauge of home building across the U.S. declined in February, driven by a drop in single-family home construction.

headline: U.S. Consumer Confidence Declined in March
summary: The Conference Board on Tuesday said its index of U.S. consumer confidence declined to 124.1 in March from 131.4 in February.

headline: Tony Hale Turned His Childhood Anxieties Into Comic Relief
summary: Before ‘Veep’ and ‘Arrested Development,’ the actor grew up dodging sports and bullies in a teen theater program

headline: This Old Mouse: ‘Golden Girls’ Unlock the Mysteries of Aging
summary: Ancient mice are important to research on aging people and command a higher price; Maine cousins live well past 125 human years‘

headline: Gut-Busting New York City Buffets That Won’t Pinch Your Wallet
summary: Fans of New York City’s food-by-the-pound ethnic buffets can still get a big, healthy meal for less than 10 bucks.

headline: ‘What We Do in the Shadows’ Gives Vampires the Faux-Documentary Treatment
summary: Based on the movie by the same name, the new TV series “What We Do in the Shadows” imagines the slightly defanged existence of vampires in modern-day Staten Island.

headline: Home-Price Growth Slows Heading Into Spring
summary: Home-price growth slowed for the 10th straight month in January, providing critical relief to buyers heading into the spring selling season.

headline: A Porsche 911 Fan Finds His Car for Life
summary: A 1972 model Lewis Eig calls ‘Blucille’—in an homage to B.B. King’s guitar—is the one he’ll stick with.

headline: Photos: A Porsche 911 for the Road
summary: Stickers on the car’s rear window commemorate past rallies with friends.

headline: Mountaintop Home in Maui
summary: A former New York resident returned to her home state of Hawaii to build a house on nearly 6 pristine acres. It is on the market for $12.8 million.

headline: Mainstream Companies Back Marijuana Banking
summary: Mainstream businesses such as fertilizer and beverage companies have joined financial firms in pressing Congress to make it easier for marijuana companies to use banks.

headline: Wayfair Is Latest Online Seller to Go Bricks and Mortar
summary: Online furniture retailer Wayfair plans to open its first physical retail store, the latest online brand to expand the way it reaches consumers by integrating the online and in-person shopping experience.

headline: Developer Counts on Selling $6 Million Condos in Asbury Park, N.J.
summary: Real estate financier Jay Sugerman saw potential in Asbury Park when its slow-moving rebound had stalled. Now, he’s hoping buyers will pay nearly $1 million to $6 million for condominiums in the once-dilapidated area.

headline: Singapore Government Taking Stake in Boutique Hotel Operator
summary: A giant Singapore government-run fund has acquired a 25% stake in Dutch hotel company citizenM, providing a cash boost to the owner and operator of microhotels, as it ramps up a global expansion.

headline: Stocks to Watch: McDonald’s, Nike, Bed Bath & Beyond, Citigroup, Wayfair
summary: Some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Tuesday’s session include McDonald’s, Canopy Growth, Nike and Red Hat

headline: White House Launches Investigation of Indian Health Service Failures Over Sexual Abuse
summary: The Trump administration will convene a task force to look into how a pediatrician was allowed to sexually abuse Native American boys for decades while working for the Indian Health Service and to try to prevent such a crime from happening again.

headline: Mastercard Invests $300 Million in Dubai Payments Firm
summary: Mastercard said it would invest $300 million in a Dubai digital-payments firm, giving the Middle East company a boost as it prepares for a London Stock Exchange debut.

headline: China’s Former Top Internet Regulator Gets 14 Years for Corruption
summary: China’s former internet regulator, Lu Wei, received a 14-year prison sentence after being convicted of corruption, a punishment the court said it lessened because he confessed.

headline: Activists Wage Fight at Bed Bath & Beyond
summary: Legion Partners, Macellum Advisors and Ancora Advisors together control a roughly 5% stake in Bed Bath & Beyond and are preparing to launch a proxy fight to replace its entire 12-person board.

headline: Why Watchmaker Patek Philippe Has No Innovation Budget
summary: Ten years into his run as head of the luxury watch company, Thierry Stern talks automation and the next generation of watches at Baselworld 2019.

headline: Boeing Selloff Is About Social Media, Not Legal Bills
summary: Investors have wiped $40 billion off Boeing’s market value this month, even though the 737 MAX crisis is unlikely to add more than $5 billion to its costs.

headline: European Banks Face a Triple Whammy
summary: Plunging bond yields have made life difficult for bank investors everywhere. For Europe’s beleaguered lenders, it is heaping pain on an already tough situation.

headline: Magical Thinking About Unicorn IPOs
summary: Investors used to complain that all the good companies were staying private, giving the ordinary shareholder no chance to buy their stock. Be careful what you wish for: Now there’s a stampede of technology unicorns IPOing.

headline: James Harden Was the MVP. Then He Became Invaluable.
summary: Inside the Houston Rockets and James Harden’s statistically incomprehensible season.

headline: Citigroup Enters Banking’s Hottest Business With New Payments Unit
summary: Citigroup is starting a consumer-payments business, joining its biggest rivals and a host of financial-technology startups jockeying for position in the hottest corner of banking.

headline: Amazon Executive to Head Unilever’s Beauty Business Amid Digital Push
summary: Unilever has appointed Amazon executive Sunny Jain to run its beauty and personal-care business, as it homes in on high-growth beauty products and works to boost its digital capabilities.

headline: AMD’s Chips Already in Google’s Big Game
summary: AMD’s special callout at Google’s event excited investors in a way the previous two mentions didn’t. AMD’s shares have jumped 12% in the week since the Google event.

headline: Dick’s Goes All Out on In-House Software
summary: Dick’s Sporting Goods is betting that building all its software in house, as opposed to relying on third-party vendors, will give it a competitive advantage.

headline: Apple Doesn’t Have Prime’s Number
summary: Apple’s extravagant unveiling of AppleTV+ unveiled very little, so what are we to make of this newest entrant into the fiercely competitive and crowded streaming race?

headline: Kamala Harris Seeks $315 Billion to Raise Teacher Pay
summary: California Sen. Kamala Harris is proposing a $315 billion plan to increase pay for public-school teachers, the first proposal from a 2020 Democratic presidential candidate to address K-12 education.

headline: Samsung Sings the Chip-Making Blues
summary: Samsung’s first-quarter profit warning should serve as a red flag to investors assuming the chip market will improve this year.

headline: Meet the WSJ Survey’s Most Accurate Economic Forecaster in 2018
summary: Bernard Baumohl, chief global economist at The Economic Outlook Group, was the most accurate forecaster for 2018 in The Wall Street Journal’s monthly survey.

headline: Japan Watchdog Accuses Citigroup Unit of Manipulating Bonds Futures Market
summary: The Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission recommended a $1.2 million fine for London-based Citigroup Global Markets.

headline: Uber Targets Middle East With $3.1 Billion Deal, Its Largest Ever
summary: The ride-hailing giant is acquiring Middle Eastern rival Careem Networks, a deal that ends another cutthroat ride-hailing battle ahead of an expected initial public offering.

headline: In Delicate Courtship, France and China Make Deals
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and China’s Xi Jinping signed a series of business and bilateral agreements on Monday, seeking to bolster their trade relationship as Paris presses Beijing to open the Chinese economy to more trade and investment.

headline: U.K. Parliament Seeks to Seize Control of Brexit Agenda
summary: Britain’s Parliament moved to pry control of the Brexit process away from Prime Minister Theresa May, forcing votes on alternatives to her unpopular plan to extract the U.K. from the European Union.

headline: Cryptocurrency Miner Bitmain’s IPO Application Lapses
summary: Bitmain Technologies, the world’s largest cryptocurrency mining company, said it plans to go public in the future after a six-month deadline on its current listing application lapsed.

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: Real-Estate Funds Have a Problem: Too Much Cash
summary: Private real-estate fund managers, sitting on record amounts of cash, are finding it increasingly difficult to spend all that money within the deadlines they promised investors.

headline: County in New York Facing Measles Outbreak Bans Unvaccinated Minors From Public Spots
summary: A New York county has declared a state of emergency over one of the worst measles outbreaks in the state in decades, banning unvaccinated minors from public places to help curb the spread of the disease.

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Prosecutors Drop All Charges Against Actor Jussie Smollett
summary: Prosecutors dropped all 16 charges against actor Jussie Smollett, who was accused of staging a hate crime against himself. The move drew strong rebukes from Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel and his police superintendent.

headline: Justice Department Sets Timetable for Mueller Report
summary: A version of Robert Mueller’s report will be available for Congress and the public within weeks, setting up the next phase in the highly charged fight over the special counsel’s findings on Russian election interference.

headline: Purdue Pharma Begins Resolution of Opioid Cases With $270 Million Deal
summary: Purdue Pharma and its owners, the Sackler family, agreed to pay $270 million to resolve claims by the Oklahoma attorney general that the company helped fuel the opioid crisis.

headline: Trump Administration Renews Attempt to Topple Affordable Care Act
summary: A Trump administration legal request to strike down the Affordable Care Act has unleashed fresh attacks from Democrats and stoked a feud among Republicans grappling over their party’s health-care message for the 2020 elections.

headline: Political Dynamics Raise Risk for Israel-Hamas Clash
summary: A fragile calm took hold between Israel and Hamas but political pressures on both sides threatened to spark a wider conflict, with Gaza’s rulers facing discontent over a poor economy and Israeli leader Netanyahu campaigning for re-election with security a key issue.

headline: Michael Avenatti’s Latest Client: A Basketball Coach
summary: Gary Franklin’s team was sponsored by Nike. Now his attorney is accused of trying to extort the sneaker company.

headline: Neiman Marcus, in Debt Talks, Makes It Easier to Bet It Will Fail
summary: Distressed-debt hedge fund Aurelius Capital Management pushed Neiman Marcus to add language to its bond documents that would make it easier to profit on bets against the retailer, especially if the company defaults.

headline: Iran Moves to Cement Its Influence in Syria
summary: On the heels of an Iranian military intervention that has helped bring President Bashar al-Assad to the edge of victory in Syria’s eight-year-long war, Tehran is moving to cement its long-term influence in Syria by cultivating goodwill and winning converts to the Shiite Muslim sect.

headline: Apple Makes Friendly With Rivals’ Devices
summary: Apple’s push into services means breaking from a business strategy centered on selling gadgets and software that were inextricably linked, keeping rivals’ devices at a distance.

headline: Would You Still Wear a Michael Jackson T-Shirt?
summary: In the wake of controversial documentaries about Michael Jackson and R. Kelly, we examine the resale market for the two performers’ merchandise.

headline: How Colin Kaepernick’s Lawyer Dealt With Nike and Became Entangled in Extortion Charges
summary: Before an alleged scheme to extort Nike with Michael Avenatti, Mark Geragos had courted the company on behalf of Colin Kaepernick.

headline: Ties Between Jews, Democratic Party Face New Pressures
summary: Growing criticism of Israel on the left is testing what has long been one of the strongest relationships in U.S. politics: Jewish Americans and the Democratic Party.

headline: A Decade After the Housing Bust, the Exurbs Are Back
summary: Home buyers, often millennials, are again trekking to the distant reaches of cities in search of affordable housing, even if that means a long commute. The collapse of this market a decade ago tore through the U.S. economy and left many builders bankrupt. They’re hoping this time will be different.

headline: Islamic State Leader Goes Low-Tech to Evade Capture
summary: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi has managed to slip through the net of the world’s intelligence agencies by shunning computers and mobile phones in favor of human messengers.

headline: Apple Makes Values Pitch, but Will People Buy It?
summary: Like many companies, Apple Inc. boasts about “social responsibility,” but very few giant corporations have infused progressive values—inclusion, equality, environmentalism—so inextricably into their brands.

headline: Turn Your Weekends Into Mini-Vacations
summary: You don’t need to leave town to think about your days of rest in a way that sends you back to work on Monday a happier person.

headline: The Sistine Chapel: A Rare Behind-the-Scenes Look at How Its Masterpieces Are Maintained
summary: Many have seen the Sistine Chapel: It welcomes nearly seven million visitors per year. But few have witnessed the inner workings of the conservation and cleaning of one of the world’s most frequented museums.

headline: Lawmakers Scrutinize Timeline for Boeing Software Fix
summary: Congressional investigators examining the FAA safety certification of Boeing’s 737 MAX aircraft also are questioning why it has taken so long to complete a safety fix initially raised in November.

headline: Turning Muslims Away, Poland Welcomes Ukrainians
summary: Poland, while fighting European Union quotas for accepting Muslim newcomers, has readily taken in Ukrainians, in the biggest wave of migration into the European Union in recent times.

headline: Don’t Just ‘Buy Now’! When Shopping on Amazon, You Need to Pay Attention
summary: Not paying enough attention while shopping on Amazon can cost you money and time. From overpriced bulk items to sub-prime Prime deals, here are some things you should know before going on buy-button autopilot.
